title: Ultimaker axis alignment tool (8mm and 6mm axis)

description.text:
This is a tool that can be used to align the axis on an Ultimaker Original / Original+ / Ultimaker 2. Since there were no good tools online available I had to create one myself.

Result... I now seriously doubt my internet search skills...

The very few available don't hold into account that you must be able to reach the allen wrench hole thingie. That can require a needed distance between the axis of roughly 40mm to 120mm. (circumfence of a 12,22mm pully is 38,39mm)

The tool gives you a 79 dregree turn from one position to the next. So from the middle to each last positions this gives you a 41 degree shift to each side.

The secret of a good alignment is that you want to be able to reach both pulleys on one belt at the same time. If you have difficulty getting the pulleys in the right position, watch this youtube video: "REFERENCE TO DELETED GOOGLE ACCOUNT SEE COMMENTS"

Use this advice at your own risk !

Printer Brand:

Ultimaker

Printer:

Ultimaker 2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0,1mm

Infill:

60%

Notes:

I used a linear fill pattern.

I advice to print this thingie using PLA. There is no aggressive click, but more a nice smooth cslide (in between click & slide) to the snuggie position.

HIPS or ABS should do the trick, but since it's an alignment thingie you should prefer PLA because of its properties.

Needed to service a borrowed printer.

  1. searched the internet for a tool like this, but couldn't find one
  2. seriously doubted my search skills
  3. got over it...
  4. designed the tool

Fact. There are over 3.3 billion internet users. Some of them have an Ultimaker printer.

As a FYI There is a License agreement with this Download and If you do download these STL file you are agreeing to the license.

Created in LightWave.

My son is graduating High School so, I made these graduation hats for his party. One holds custom M&Ms with his face on it from http://www.mymms.com/home.do. The hole in middle of the hat is cup cake size. The other one holds custom cookies with his face on them as well. Cookie size is 2.75 inches Diameter. From http://www.zazzle.com. The tassel I used colored twine about 13 inch long. I folded it and cut a few times to get the right length. I used 20 gage metal wire from the bracelet area at my local hobby store.I drilled a hole in the top only(do not go all the way though). tide a knot or two then stuff the hole then used extruder to fill hole with filament by manually pushing til hole was full then used pliers to smooth while still hot so you need to move quickly. Don't let the hot nozzle hit the twine it will melt it.

To print them flip so top is down with supports. I did have some warping issues but I found a fix so if you have problems let me know.

title: Filament spool holder ends for a 10mm bar

description.text:
UPDATE 2017-06-19
Not recommended approach for a spool holder

This approach is really awkward as you have to faff about with different spindle diameters, etc. etc. I've gone away from this and now use https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:629381. This is a much simpler, easier to use and more reliable spool holder. I strongly recommend it to you too. It's a bit more material and needs four 608 bearings, but trust me when I say that you won't regret it.

Original summary below

My JGAURORA A3 printer came with a nice filament mount that has a 10mm threaded bar to hold the filament spool. Unfortunately, the filaments that I bought have much larger diameter holes through the middle and don't rotate smoothly.

These are trivially simple ends to center the filament spool on the 10mm bar. One has a diameter of ~53mm and the other ~50mm. I need both for the various filaments that I have.

With these in place, the filaments spin smoothly. You need to print two of whatever size you want - one for each end of the spool.

author: rogerlucas

description.text:
I was having trouble feeding some inexpensive(very) PLA filament, in which the extruder had trouble pulling the reel forward due to how much larger diameter the reel hole is with respect to the Wanhao Duplicator/Monoprice Maker's spool holder arm.
I created a fresh OpenSCAD file to fit the spool holder arm.
This was Inspired by the T-Slot mount spool holder by npushis https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:70275.

Both the inner diameter and outer diameter are customizable, and I have had great results so far. My inner diameter ended up being just a bit too tight, but I was able to shave out some of the plastic with a pocket knife, and make it fit.
The adapter hubs fit snugly on the spool holder and do not rotate, but the filament reel freely rotates about the hubs. I positioned the hubs with about an extra mm between themselves and the reel to avoid adding extra friction.

Printer:

Wanhao Duplicator i3/Monoprice Maker 3P

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

10%

Fit on the spool holder is too tight

You can shave a bit of the plastic out of the inner diameter with a pocket knife (Gerber multi tool, or whatever) until it fits, just snug. Not sure if it would be better if it fit loosely, but my spool holder has a texture to it that would put quite a bit of friction on the part anyway.

Simple OpenSCAD document

Simply the difference of the union of two cylinders (out hub diameter and rim) and a third cylinder representing the diameter of the spool holder.

author: Poppeseed

description.text:
This is a Malyan M150 Bed Leveling Thumbwheel. It was designed to clear the front/back rails and maximize grip leverage on M3 nylock nuts. Using nylock nuts on the bed leveling posts will keep the level in-tune longer which will give you more consistent first layer adhesion.

Print at 50% fill for strength.
Print four thumbwheels.

Additional hardware required:

  • four M3 nyloc nuts
  • four M3 washers

The tolerances in this print are tight.

  • Use an M3 screw to verify the hole is clear before attempting to install thumbwheel.
  • Push an M3 nylock nut (flat side first) in with a suitable tool (like a screwdriver) till fully seated.
  • Install a M3 washer between the top of the thumbwheel and the bottom of the aluminum sub plate.
  • Re-level the bed, and it should now stay level a lot longer.

This file has been modified to clear the Y axis Home Limit Switch mounting screws. I had to make it significantly smaller to also account for potential bowing of the bed posts to clear the back rail. These smaller thumbwheels still allow manually turning M3 Nylocs without using any tools. The larger original file works on the front posts only.

The tricky parts are clearing the hole with an M3 screw before attempting to put it on a bed post and forcing the Nyloc past a fat first layer.

Printer:

Malyan M150

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Infill:

50%
Tinkercad

author: mosteveo

description.text:
Simple and very useful

The Problem

    It is my little project to solve the same problem that I always have, every time I mount a new model.

    A. Depends on the frame I don't have a *specific place to tie the wires*;
    B. There are *no correct place to RX*;
    C. There are *no correct place the buzzy*;
    D. I need cut a *lot of pieces of foam* to put FC, the manner *not conduct vibration* between the model, when it is turned on, and the FC.

The Solution

    So, now I have all these problem solved, and better: with a nice style.
    The first time that I made it, was to use with KK2, buy the way, use the same foam that the KK2 is delivery. After that I used to with many FC,just cut a piece of foam with 70mm X 70mm X 25mm and accommodate your preferred FC.
    There are holes to fix the support in "x" or "+" configuration.

    Please, fill free to comment, reuse or do any modification.

I redesigned this in scad with a 15mm spacer instead of the 1/2 used on the original.  My MK7 came with 5/8" mm spacers.  Fits a Sharpie Fine Point just like to original thing.
I may add a "tab" to it that sits on the side of the heatsink to keep it in a more stable position.

Print - (I printed with 30% infill and 1 shell - 2 shells might be optimal).
Mount in the left or right fan spacer position (I put an o-ring in to prevent slippage to fill in the 0.875 mm gap)
Install Sharpie fine point marker
Plot If you don't want to use an O-ring change the spacer height to 15.875 in the OpenScad file.

title: Geared Jack
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
This is a simple jack that I built to show how gears work, and the affect of a gearing ratio on the ease of use. This uses 2 gears that are a that are 1/2 in. and 2 in. across. I designed this to have triangle cutouts, which cut down on weight while lousing very little structural strength, which allows the jack to use the minimal plastic, and time to print.
To assemble, you must first print off all parts, then you put the rectangular base on to the upright base, don't worry if the fit is tight, it is suppose to be. Then you take the peg that the big gear goes around, and the little gear that has the shaft thought it, and put then the big gear on the peg, the gears should mess tightly, so it might be difficult to put them together at first. After that you take the jack part that goes up and down, and put it into the open slot that is left, you may have to sand the wall that the jack rubs against until the jack moves with little effort when you push it up and down. Finally you put on the front cover, and after you do that you put on the handle on to the small gear shaft, on the side that protrudes threw farther. The shaft is meant to be a flush fit, so you may have to sand the inside of the circle that fits around the shaft, but use a very fine sandpaper, and check your work constantly, because you don't want to make the hole too big, because then it will just spin around the shaft, and not turn the gears to lift the jack.
P.S. The front plate that is labeled front of jack 2 is an alternative front plate that I designed to use less material, and it shows how the big gear messes with the toothed jack.

title: Ribbed Sidewall Interlocking Stackerz
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
This is a "RIBBED SIDEWALL" version of my regular Interlocking Stackerz. View at http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1546446. The Ribbed Sidewall makes them look smart as well as being easier for some people to grip for locking / unlocking. Please refer to the details provided below and at the original Interlocking Stackerz page for additional information (Note: Some content has been copied directly over as this is the same design other than having a ribbed sidewall on all parts).

Ribbed Version stl's have an "R" in the file name. This was listed separately to avoid possible confusion and mixing the types up.

There is also a fun / novelty version called 'ROCKETZ' you can find at http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1563995

Interlocking Stackerz are easy prints of a clever modular storage and transport solution that features interlocking sections of different sizes to suit an endless array of applications. Use them to store and/or transport anything and everything small including nuts / bolts / screws to medication etc.

The mechanism is simple... just push two parts together and rotate 120° to lock in place. Additional parts lock together in the same way... reverse to unlock and separate the parts.

Interlocking Stackerz provide a simple solution to storing and transporting things. For example, store a range of nuts / bolts / screws in them and they become a 'grab and go' item so you can take what you need with you without a second thought.... and different items are in different layers to keep the separate.

The internal diameter is the same for all parts (60mm at standard scale). The .stl files provided are as follows:
•Cap
•Layer / Low (15mm high storage area)
•Layer / Medium (25mm high storage area)
•Layer / High (50mm high storage area)
•Base / Low (15mm high storage area)
•Base / Medium (25mm high storage area)
•Base / High (50mm high storage area)

Print the parts required to make up your ideal configuration in the colors of choice... color coding makes it easy to find what you have stored way.

Interlocking Stackerz are easy to print and do not need any support. On a well set up, accurate machine well sliced files should provide a snug fit between parts that still lets them turn to lock / unlock without much effort.

Please refer to the print settings and images for additional information.... and post photos of your Interlocking Stackerz in use.

Note: If you like this check out the rest of my practical and fun designs!

Notes:

Easy prints... on a well set up machine with PLA the parts should slide together and rotate to lock / unlock with minimal effort.

Just push together and rotate to lock in place...

If your Interlocking Stackerz are tight to join / turn this is most likely due to machine and/or slicing app capability. Try increasing the scale uniformly by 3 - 5% to increase clearances. You can also give the locking parts a quick spray with silicone lubricant to make them slide together and rotate more easily.

comments.text: Easy to change... but as my designs need to work for as many people as possible, and every machine and slicing app creates a slightly different result (not to mention filament) I've learned it's better to be a fraction big / loose than too tight because then they don't work and people aren't happy!

title: DJI Phantom 2+ Floats - Bottle Mount Adapter
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
It should go without saying... but:

Use this at your own risk!

I've wanted a couple of times to fly the drone from a boat but have been worried about it returning to "home" and landing in the water. Flying your Phantom over water, are you crazy?! Perhaps rabbit...

I've had this idea in my head since the lab got the drone and when I finally sat down to model it it took very little time.

PLEASE NOTE: This model assumes you have already purchased prop guards because you'll have to use the longer (M3x12?) screws to attach the bottle mounts.

Here's is some of the test flight video:
https://youtu.be/OZ3Fn_VCUUo

description.text: Ultimaker 2 - Filament Spool Holder 25mm Diameter and about 70mm Long.

Printer Brand:

Ultimaker

Printer:

Ultimaker 2

Replacement pulp guard for a "power juicer".  
A friend acquired a broken "Power Juicer" and fixed it up, however it was missing the pulp guard and catch basin.  While tying a bag to the pulp output port works, it still makes quite a mess... so we have the technology to build one!

This pulp guard probably doesn't work with the real container, as we didn't have one to use.  Measuring the juicer with calipers was quite the pain, as the shape did not make it easy -- the values may be slightly off based on your printer's tolerances, but I believe they should be fine.  
I printed the two halves ("juicer_thing.stl" and "juicer_thing_mirror.stl") and acetoned them together.  For those people with a large enough build platform, use the full piece ("juicer_thing_full.stl").  
We still use a plastic bag to catch the pulp, but at least it doesn't go flying everywhere, and the bag is easier to tie up.  
To make washing the guard easier, I acetone-smoothed the entire piece using a preval sprayer, followed by a few wipes using an acetone-soaked cotton ball.

comments.text: ha .. these things ... fun but .. usually come cheaply with the critical pulp catcher and the in the jack lalane brand the blade loosener.

title: Alexa Notifier Flag
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
The Amazon Echo AKA "Alexa" is great for setting reminders, making lists, leaving messages, etc. Unfortunately, there is no way to know "She" has something for you, no flashing light, no beeping, nothing. You could send a text message, email or leave a post-it note but that defeats the purpose.

Alexa Notifier Flag is reminiscent of the ones used on mailboxes. After leaving you list or message with Alexa flip the flag up. With a glance, you or others will know she has something to tell you. Once you get the information just flip the flag back down.

The flag is pretty thin and should be print with 100% in-fill.
The Base Ring parts can be printed with 20% infill.
All the parts have 0.5mm tolerances, press fit together and only need minimal cleanup.
The Assembled file is for reference only and should not be printed.

Enjoy.

title: Motorizable replacement crank for circular knitting machine

description.text:
Part of a bigger project to reverse-engineer and make a fully 3d-printable circular knitting machine. https://github.com/jonnor/projects/tree/master/idda-knitting-machine

This lets you replace the crank of your circular knitting machine, in case it broke down or you want to attach a motor to it. Can connect a drill to the crank using a 3mm Allen key bit, or a custom motor via the MXL belt pulley.
A complete mod for motorizing these knitting machines is expected soon.

The device this is for is sold for instance by Banggood as "Creative DIY Scarf Hat Quick Knitting Machine Handheld Handwork Weaving Tool for Adult Child"
http://www.banggood.com/Creative-DIY-Scarf-Hat-Quick-Knitting-Machine-Handheld-Handwork-Weaving-Tool-for-Adult-Child-p-1030934.html

comments.text: Has anyone designed an STL for the whole machine?
comments.author: Puuka

comments.text:
Not that I am aware. The linked project has come work-in-progress models in FreeCAD.
https://github.com/jonnor/idda-knitting-machine
There are also reference images of the working mechanism there.

author: bhahimuth

print_settings.Notes:: Any resolution will do, I used fast PLA settings as I wasn't going for any aesthetic here, just function.

description.text: We own the Simplehuman brand automatic soap dispenser. We use it for dish soap in our kitchen. It works perfectly and looks great on the 3D printed platform that keeps it nice and level on the sink and doubles as a hole plug when we changed our faucet. The drawback is that this thing sucks batteries and they always run out when the tank is full which is not removable so you wind up standing on your head to try to replace the batteries with a sink full of dirty dishes. Enough!! This project is a power adapter for this divice but would probably work for anything that uses 4 AA batteries in 2, 2 battery columns that are in series. I didn't want to drill a hole in the bottom of the factory plug which has a nice seal so I printed a plug that twist-locks in place but it is exactly the same height as the original.

Printer:

XYZ Pro

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

Quick and dirty (.3)

Infill:

15%

Notes:

Any resolution will do, I used fast PLA settings as I wasn't going for any aesthetic here, just function.

How to assemble...

After printing, I used some copper wire to loop across both the positve nad negative terminals. Twisting them together, I mad a small loop in the end to solder to. I filled the ends with silicone (white so you could see it) to hold things firmly in place leaving the solder loops exposed. I took a small 5V .6A power supply that was left over from another project (the 5V works fine for this device) and soldered the wire in the correct polarity. You should be able to see all of that in the photograph if you zoom in.

The holder for a servo motor that can attach to 2 dowel rods.

Dragon Bridge

"The settlement is a small village, but what is most notable is from what it derived its name from―the bridge that arches across the Karth River there. When crossing the bridge, a giant statue of a dragon's head is on an arch over the roadway in the middle, hence the name. From there, Solitude is visible above the mouth of the river as towers in the distance. "

Extracted from Skyrim, cleaned up and converted to STL.

I thought it would be good for anyone looking fantasy bridges for tabletop wargaming.

Original design remains the property of Bethesda and shouldn't be used for commercial purposes.
I have not printed this yet as I do not have a printer. It may need editing to successfully print. The stress analysis in meshmixer has flagged that the dragons may be weak points

description.text: They're height adjustable to make it easy to level your bot and has a slot on the bottom to add a rubber band or washer of some sort to help cushion it and reduce vibrations and noise. I'm not sure how much quieter it is, so might need thicker O-Rings on the bottoms. The holes are tricky to get right so that the nuts and bolts fit snuggly, might need editing for your makerbot skeinforge settings. They attach to the MakerBot by tightly squeezing and pinching onto the side panel so they're pretty easy to take on and off. Could also design different bottoms to screw into them. I might try making something like the RepRap Anti-Vibration Feet: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:808

You'll need to print 4 bottom pieces and 2 left and 2 right top pieces. Press a 16mm O-Ring into the groove in the bottom piece (or better yet, use scratch guard pads like these: http://www.officedepot.com/a/products/618348/Master-Caster-Scratch-Guard-Self-Adhesive/) Screw a 16mm M3 bolt into the bottom piece, all the way in so the head is level with the bottom side Stick an M3 nut into the large hole in the top piece Screw the bolt w/ bottom piece into the top piece Slot them it into the bottom of your makerbot, make sure the square part is flush with the bottom of bot, twist the bottom pieces to adjust height

description.text:
I used blender to split the original model so that base and the Aleph are each a separate color/material, flattened the base, and scaled the whole thing up so that the model stands just a hair shy of 110 mm tall. It was a bit over 130 mm for the previous revision, but I started from the original model again, and didn't scale it up as much.

Along with the separate "letter", "base", and "support" pieces, I've included my .blend file as well.

I originally intended these to be printed with a dual/multi-extruder setup, but you can also print these with one extruder, one color at a time, if you arrange the pieces properly and then "split" them (as Slic3r calls it). Use both support pieces for dual extrusion, and just "support 1" for single.

When the pieces are loaded, you'll find index/alignment squares next to the base. Position things so that the base's mark is to the right (+X) of the Aleph's mark, and the two supports' marks are right behind (+Y) them. Taken together, the four should form a perfect square with no gaps between them.

Update: 2016-07-15: Simplified the geometry a bit and made the model printable as separate pieces, without using dual extruders.
Update: 2016-07-16: added custom support material for the upper Yod, so that you don't have to use your slicer's automatic supports.
Update: 2016-07-17: put a ~0.2mm gap between the "support 1" piece and the upper Yod (it was adhering to the Yod too well)

Printer Brand:

RepRap

Printer:

Prusa i3

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

15%

Notes:

With the low infill percentage, be sure you use an ample number perimeters and top solid layers. If you have an especially-good cooling setup, you can omit support objects entirely.

In any case, make sure you have GOOD anti-ooze settings in place if you're doing this with dual extrusion.

You may want to apply some custom settings to the support objects to reduce their density and number of perimeters, so as not to waste filament.
Some trimming with an X-acto knife. Vapor smoothing recommended.

I imported stevemedwin's original STL into blender, scaled it up, and did a "limited dissolve" over the whole model, with a threshold of 1 degree. Then I separated the Aleph from the base part, made both solid/manifold, extruded the bottom of the Aleph and flattened the bottom of the extrusion to create short mounting studs. I then copied those studs to a new object, scaled them up a bit, and used the result to cut corresponding holes into the base, with a nominal 0.15mm gap around all sides. Finally, I created custom support objects for the Aleph's upper Yod segment.

title: WANHAO Duplicator i3 v2 MicroSd to SD card Adaptor Holder

description.text:
Since I didn't like using tiny Micro SD Memory cards that could fall into the cracks of my workbench, I purchased on Amazon.ca (ASIN: B01CY0VO3U) an adapter that goes from MicroSd to standard SD Cards. But there was still 2 issues. The first issue was to secure and locate the adapter on the control box and the second issue was that the MicroSD end cable of the adapter is really sticking out of the control box, putting it at high risk of breaking it by accident. So I decided to design a bracket that would hold the adapter while also protecting the fragile connector. I made the design so I could snap the holder inside 4 venting holes, 2 per sides.

Just be careful when you print it to orient the part so your slicer orients the internal support in lengthwise direction. Otherwise, you could end up with hard to remove internal supports.

author: JF_Chabot

description.text:
This was inspired by thing 19026. I was new to 3D printing and thought printing this would be hard because of the large unsupported curves. I didn't like the way s;ic3r put in support (too hard to remove), and I was learning OpenSCAD, so I thought I'd try to design something similar make something similar so I could play around with printing "hard parts (arches and pins and sockets), and put in my own support.

The code isn't the cleanest, and the design isn't as pretty as the inspiration, but I finally decided I might as well put it out.

I printed it in PLA on my Prusa Mendel i2 RepRap.

Most of the parameters to control size, number of shells, etc. appear near the top of the .scad file. I think most are reasonably self-explanatory. The stl files are generated from the .scad file as posted.

There are several alternative top level modules. Uncomment the appropriate one at the bottom of the file.

Top level "showPrintable" will generate the shells, which are all printed together, nested. After printing, snip out the support in each vertical opening and the band of rafting at the bottom that holds the pieces together on the print bed. Then fit the pins of each shell into the sockets of its parent (requires stretching the arms out a bit).

Top level "stand" prints a stand for displaying the gyro.

Top level "showAssembled" does not generate printable stl, but will show how the shells fit together when printed. If you animate this one in OpenSCAD (I suggest 100 steps at perhaps 3 frames per second), you will see how the shells spin inside each other.

Gneisenau was a German capital ship, alternatively described as a battleship and battlecruiser, of Nazi Germany's Kriegsmarine. She was the second vessel of her class, which included one other ship, Scharnhorst. The ship was built at the Deutsche Werke dockyard in Kiel; she was laid down on 6 May 1935 and launched on 8 December 1936. Completed in May 1938, the ship was armed with a main battery of nine 28 cm (11 in) C/34 guns in three triple turrets, though there were plans to replace these weapons with six 38 cm (15 in) SK C/34 guns in twin turrets.

Gneisenau and Scharnhorst operated together for much of the early portion of World War II, including sorties into the Atlantic to raid British merchant shipping

description.text:
This is an adapter to replace the default 28byj-48 with a NEMA 17 motor for ToyREP (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:945156) by Thorgal. It requires no modification to the machine except you will need a longer belt and a 5mm pulley. I recommend an aluminum 20 tooth pulley (over the printed pulleys provided), and while your at it upgrade to a GT2 belt instead of a T2.5 (which is not designed for linear motion.) My steps per mm on 16x microstepping with a 20t pulley is ~80 steps/mm. You can calculate your steps per mm here: http://prusaprinters.org/calculator/

I have more coming including this part integrated into the ToyREP-X1 part, and a Y axis adapter.
I might get around to making adapters for different sized NEMA motors if there is enough demand (tell me in the comments!)

Pulleys are from http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:16627

NOTE: I know the motor isn't on straight in the pictures, I only had two screws in it at the time. Also, the last two pictures shown are of the adapter uploaded here, the orange adapter is a previous version.

ToyREP

20%

Notes:

Slic3r is recommended because it detects the thin parts that need reinforcement like near the screw holes.

Trial and error with the spacing and the hole sizes.

title: Adjustable Step Up And Step Down Voltage DC Power Supply Box

description.text:
This is a power supply I built using inexpensive parts available on e-bay. I find I need a variety of voltages for powering fans and other devices. Features include:
  • Independent adjustable step up and step down voltage regulators. The step down supply source is switchable between the input source or the step up supply output
  • Two voltmeters to monitor input and output voltages. One meter can be switched to either input source or the step down supply output while the other continuously monitors the step up supply output
  • Four panel mount 5.5 x 2.1mm DC power jacks (one source in, one step up output, one step down output, and one source in pass through output.
    A bill of materials is included along with a schematic of the circuits for assembly. Total cost for parts is < $35USD if you have to purchase everything. Although not cost effective vs. buying separate supplies, it does tuck in nicely behind my Replicator 2X and is very functional. Best of all it's 3D printed!
    The design files provided are Cubify Design from 3D Systems (formerly Alibre).
    I have a heavy duty 12V supply I power this supply box with. I step up the voltage to 24V for some fans I use, and I step down the voltage to 7-8V for fans that need driven less than full power, or pass through the 12V supply to use directly.
    The circuit connections are straight forward but there are 20 wires to cut and solder, 16 screws to drive, and two switches to mount - plan on a couple hours for assembly.

See the attached power_supply_BOM.pdf file for a bill of materials and the items to search and purchase on e-bay.  You can search directly on the BOM description.  I've also provided a sample device e-bay item number, although over time these will become obsolete.  
The StepUpDwnSchematic.pdf file captures a schematic of the circuits to show you how to wire the components.  I cut a protoboard down to size and drilled two 3mm holes for mounting on 0.600" centers.  A picture is provided.  This board is used as a wiring junction for the source in V+, the source in V-, and the step up regulator supply V+ net.  There are seven source in V+ wires, four source in V- wires, and three step up regulator V+ wire connections.  The others nets have only one or two wires, with the regulator output nets having the two wires. I soldered the second wire directly to the regulator output pad w/o issue.  Note I soldered the wires to the bottom of the regulator pads as this helps keep the wiring below the regulators.  
The cut out on the box lid allows access to the resistor pots to adjust the regulator voltages.  Be sure the regulator boards are oriented correctly so the resistor pots are accessible with the box lid installed.  
Look at the supply box top labels to determine which voltage regulator goes where, what each voltmeter is, and how to orient the switches correctly.  The box has labels for what each 2.1mm DC jack is.  Coupled with the schematic the circuit layout will become apparent.  I ensured there was plenty of room around the DC jacks, thus you can easily modify the holes for different DC jacks if you want w/o likely requiring other rework.  
I've printed these with Makerware standard settings with ABS successfully. 10% infill, 2 shells, 0.20mm layer height.  
I used this project to learn the CAD software as I am new to 3D printing. There are likely improvements that can be made, yet I've found the design very useful and thought it was worth sharing.

author: davepaxz

title: Can Crusher: A Torque Vs. Speed Project (WIP)

description.text:
Hi, I am a 16 year old (about to turn 17) student who is involved in multiple afterschool programs focus around STEM. I have designed this project to show younger students how different gears play a key factor in Mechanical Advantage, while also crushing some cans!

While doing this project, be sure to have the proper safety equipment!

For each project, I recommend printing out the following:
(2) First Dowel Inserts
(2) Second Dowel Inserts
(1) Large Gear
(1) Large Handle Gear
(1) Small Gear
(1) Extra Large Handle Gear
(6) Crusher Gears

Overview & Background:

By completing this project, students or young engineers can learn about the effectiveness of torque vs speed through the use of gears, and crushing cans!

Objectives:
  1. The use of Torque in an everyday life
  2. The job that different sized gears play
  3. An example of Mechanical Advantage
Audiences:

6th-9th Grade Students with an interest in engineering.

Subjects:

Math
Science
Engineering

Skills Learned (Standards):

Students will be able to identify the mechanical advantage of using different sized gears.

Lesson/Activity:

Parts List:

(1) small cardboard box
(2) ½” wooden dowels
Duck tape
Pen
Ruler
Assorted Metal Cans
Scissors/Exacto Knife
Safety Goggles
Super glue

3D Printed Parts:
(2) First Dowel Inserts
(2) Second Dowel Inserts
(1) Large Gear
(1) Large Handle Gear
(1) Small Gear
(1) Extra Large Handle Gear
(6) Crusher Gears

Procedure:

  1. Place all parts on the work surface and count to make sure you have all of the correct parts needed. Push the 3D printed parts to the side, and place the Box, Pen, Ruler, Duck Tape, and Exacto Knife in front of you.
  2. Duck Tape the flaps of the box up, so it’s taller than before. Make sure all four corners are secure.
  3. Use the Ruler to measure and mark lines at at least 2 ½” from both sides, and 2” down from these marks. It should make a plus sign. These will be the center of the holes for the dowels. Next, measure a quarter inch from the plus, and draw a circle all the way around. Do the same to the opposite side.
  4. Carefully cut out the circles and pop all 4 out, and check that they are lined up with the holes on the opposite side. Check that these are the right size by pushing the dowels into the holes all the way through.
  5. Push aside the Duck Tape, Exacto Knife, Pen, and Ruler, and get your Dowel Inserts and dowels ready, and push one end of the dowel into a First Dowel Insert. Take 3 of your crusher gears onto the dowel and space them out a little more than 1 inch apart. Repeat for the next dowel. Make sure they won't clash with the Crusher gears on the other side, and super glue them in place.
  6. Push the dowels through to the other side of the box, and place the Second Dowel Inserts onto your dowels. Make sure that the dowel can spin, and also that the dowel is sticking out at least 1 inch on one side.
  7. Congrats! You built your crusher! Move the Crusher gears around to meet up with each other but make sure they won’t collide.
Duration:

About one hour

Preparation:
  1. What is Mechanical Advantage (not how to calculate it)
  2. The dangers of moving gears and sharp metal
Rubric & Assessment:

At the end of this, the students should be able to talk about and write about how different sized gears gave them an advantage, or didn't help them. The box should be mostly intact.

Handouts & Assets:

In the "Thing Files" section of this project, there is a printer friendly assignment that I have created.

description.text:
This is a cover for the back of the JD robot from http://www.ez-robot.com

Included are .stl files for the complete backpack and a split version with top and bottom to save in print material and time.

The project history can be found on the EZ-Robot forum at: http://www.ez-robot.com/Community/Forum/Thread?threadId=9352

Only the custom back cover for JD is included here. If you require the other JD robot .stl files you can obtain those from EZ-Robot at http://www.ez-robot.com

If you print the split version you'll need to glue them together and I would recommend using an ABS glue made from heavy duty acetone and ABS bits (assuming you are print in ABS vs. PLA). Other glues or hot glue should be fine as well, but I prefer ABS glue. Or you could drill small holes in the corners and screw the two pieces together with small screws.

There are two versions of the bottom, one has a sold flat back and one has an open back.

Notes:

When printing the two part version, I use a little higher resolution or infill for the top.

This draws a buildbox with the dimensions of your 3D printer
Based on the build_plate module, see http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:44094
Note : be sure to also install write.scad, see http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:16193

In your OpenSCAD file add the following line :
use
this make OpenSCAD aware of the build_box module Usage:
build_box(rangeX,rangeY,rangeZ,planes,labels);
where:
rangeX = range of 3D printer along X-axis, default=200
rangeY = range of 3D printer along Y-axis, default=200
rangeZ = range of 3D printer along Z-axis, default=200
planes = the planes you want to see, default = "XYZ"
for only Z-plane enter "Z"
labels = true if you want labels, default=true Then draw the build box by
//build_box(200,200,200,"XYZ",true);
//build_box(200,200,200,"Z",false); // buildplate
//build_box(200,200,200);
//build_box(200);
build_box();
color("red")
cube([5,4,200],center=false);

EDIT: I added a base for the cube with mounting posts for the Trinket and Neopixel boards, and updated the cube to include a cutout for the USB power. Use MinecraftOre_A_v2.stl with the original MinecraftOre_B.stl, plus MinecraftOre_Base_v2.stl. The base should pressure fit into the cube with no need for glue or mounting hardware.

I have also provided the combined A+B parts to save you a step when printing on a dual extruder. (MinecraftOre_AB_v2.amf.xml)

Enjoy!

This is a Minecraft Ore block that is illuminated from the inside with a Neopixel RGB LED module. By changing the color, you can make it look like iron, redstone, diamond, emerald, lapis, or even gold ore.

The block is 64mm on a side.

Printed on a dual extruder using natural PLA for the veins and grey for the body with 100% infill.

//
//  Adafruit Trinket with NeoPixel Night Light.
//  Meant to be embedded in a Minecraft Ore cube.
//
//  Wire a pushbutton from GPIO #3 to GND.
//  NeoPixel DI connects to GPIO #2
//  NeoPixel power to +5V and GND to GND (or GPIO #1 as a convenience.)
//

#include <Adafruit_NeoPixel.h>
#ifdef __AVR_ATtiny85__ // Trinket, Gemma, etc.
 #include <avr/power.h>
#endif

#define PIN_DOUT 2  // #2 is connected to the DI pin on the NeoPixel
#define PIN_GND  1  // #1 is used as GND for the NeoPixel, for convenience.
#define PIN_BUTTON_A 3

// Initialize a string of one LED on pin #2
Adafruit_NeoPixel pixels = Adafruit_NeoPixel(1, PIN_DOUT);

#define N_COLORS  (8)
uint32_t colors[N_COLORS]  =
{
  0xFF0000,  // Red  (Redstone)
  0x7FFFFF,  // Cyan  (Diamond)
  0xFF3F00,  // Orange  (Copper)
  0x00FF00,  // Green  (Emerald)
  0x0000FF,  // Blue  (Lapis Lazuli)
  0xFF7F00,  // Yellow  (Gold)
  0xFF00FF,  // Magenta
  0xFFFFFF,  // White
};

int nColor = 0;
uint32_t fadeTime;
uint32_t t;
uint32_t pressTime;
int buttonState = 0;  // 0=released, 1=debounce, 2=pressed

uint8_t r = 0;
uint8_t g = 0;
uint8_t b = 0;
uint8_t r1 = 0;
uint8_t g1 = 0;
uint8_t b1 = 0;

void advanceColor() {
    nColor++;    // Next color
    if (nColor >= N_COLORS)
      nColor = 0;

   uint32_t color = colors[nColor];
   r1 = 0xFF & (color >> 16);
   g1 = 0xFF & (color >> 8);
   b1 = 0xFF & (color);
}

void refreshColor() {
  if (r < r1)
    r = r + 1;
  else if (r > r1)
    r = r - 1;

  if (g < g1)
    g = g + 1;
  else if (g > g1)
    g = g - 1;

  if (b < b1)
    b = b + 1;
  else if (b > b1)
    b = b - 1;

    uint32_t color = r;
    color = (color << 8) | g;
    color = (color << 8) | b;
    pixels.setPixelColor(0, color);
    pixels.show();
}

void setup() {
#ifdef __AVR_ATtiny85__ // Trinket, Gemma, etc.
  if(F_CPU == 16000000) clock_prescale_set(clock_div_1);
#endif

  // Set button pin as input:
  pinMode(PIN_BUTTON_A, INPUT_PULLUP);
  // Setting input pins to high turns on internal pull-up resistors:
  digitalWrite(PIN_BUTTON_A, HIGH);

  // Set GND pin for NeoPixel as output and LOW:
  pinMode(PIN_GND, OUTPUT);
  digitalWrite(PIN_GND, LOW);

  pixels.begin();
  //pixels.setBrightness(85); // 1/3 brightness
  pixels.setBrightness(255);  // Full brightness

  advanceColor();
  fadeTime = millis();
  refreshColor();
}

void loop() {

  t = millis();

  // Must debounce the button on Pin #3 in case we're
  // powered off USB of an actual computer.
  // The USB host will pulse the data line and fake us out otherwise.
  if (digitalRead(PIN_BUTTON_A) == LOW)
  {
    if (buttonState == 0)
    {
      pressTime = t;
      buttonState = 1;
    }
    else if ((buttonState == 1) && ((t - pressTime) >= 60))
    {
      advanceColor();
      buttonState = 2;
    }
  }
  else
  {
    buttonState = 0;
  }

  if ((t - fadeTime) > 3) {
    refreshColor();
    fadeTime = t;
  }
}

print_settings.Notes:: Note that the road bed and the assembly jigs can both be printed with a standard nozzle.

description.text:
I have been doing a series of models in 1:100 scale and while many of them can be scaled to 1:160, or N-Scale, this is the first model designed for that scale. It is my first attempt and there are a number of things about the design that I don't like and will alter in future designs. That said it is still a nice example of what can be done ... ASSUMING YOU HAVE A SMALL NOZZLE FOR YOUR PRINTER (please see the notes under print settings)!

Note that the roadbed is 160x17mm with the total width, including the walkways, being 26mm. The bridge structure, not including the handrails or support pillars, is 18mm tall.

Update of 22-May-2016: One of the Sketchup components was corrupt (though not the corresponding STL) and the side panels needed extra bracing at the ends.

Update of 24-May-2016: Embarrassing but I just noticed that when I borrowed the railing from another model I must have miss-scaled it as it ended up being two feet tall. Picture of assembled bridge still not accurate but the renderings are updated with the STL file.

Update of 30-May-2016: Bottom.stl may have been corrupt. Walkway now four feet wide as it should be.

Printer Brand:

Ultimaker

Printer:

Ultimaker 2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

125 microns

Notes:

All models, source and STLs, are saved in full scale and need to be factored down to N-Scale! This means downsizing by/to 0.625. I model in full scale because Sketchup Pro solid functions seem to get confused by tiny little things.

This model will not print well, if at all, with a "normal" sized nozzle. It is designed for a 250 micron (or smaller) nozzle with the walkway demanding an extrusion width of 250 microns. You can force a larger nozzle to small extrusion widths but the quality will degrade the further you push.

Note that the road bed and the assembly jigs can both be printed with a standard nozzle.

Assembly

There are two model files that can be printed to provide assembly jigs for the bridge. One goes on the outside of the top with the two sides then positioned on that piece with the other jig on the inside holding the sides in place. The inner jig can also be used to help position the inner cross braces.

title: Small Electric Vehicle / E-Bike / E-Motorcycle J1772 Charger Adapter

description.text:
Charge adapter for a Dostar J1772 inlet to an IEC power cable.
Useful for charging e-bikes and other lower powered electric vehicles from public charging stations, or just sharing your already conveniently placed garage/outdoor personal J1772 charger with your small electric vehicles as well as your big ones.

Printer Brand:

LulzBot

Printer:

TAZ 5

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Notes:

Printed with high strength Taulman 910 Nylon and subsequently dyed black with nylon-compatible fabric dye and sealed for moisture proofing with some clear spray sealant.

Rubber gaskets were lasercut with a 60W CO2 laser. (3 gaskets total, two for the sides of the interior box, and one for the top waterproof button)

Secured with some 50mm M5-.08 flat-head screws, and a cable strain relief milled from rubber round stock for the cable side.

title: Australian Tube Products (ATP) Bar Plugs
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Australian Tube Products (ATP) was a company that made handlebars and stems for bicycles. In the 1950’s they produced handlebars with plastic bar plugs. Over the past 60 years, the plastic plugs were either lost, deteriorated from UV exposure, or damaged upon removal.

ATP bars have a 19mm internal diameter with a 21.75mm outer diameter. Other bars from the era had an I.D. of 19.5mm, but the same O.D. of ~21.75mm. So to make these plugs suit all types of bars, I've made the plugs slightly tapered, from 19mm to 19.6mm. It should end up a snug fit in the larger diameter bars, but still be able to be pressed tightly into the smaller diameter ATP bars.

Printer:

CTC

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

20%

Notes:

ABS is the preferred material due to sun exposure.

I printed at 0.2mm layer height for a good balance between print speed and detail. 2 shells with 0.4mm nozzle will be adequate.

This component was drawn up in Solidworks with measurements and a reference image of the original bar plug.

The Solidworks part file has been included for those who would like to make any adjustments.

print_settings.Notes:: The inner hole for the 3mm screw runs almost all the way across the part. Watch the print so you can see how far you need to drill and tap.

description.text: For those of you who have the Folgertech Kossel 2020 printer, you will be aggravated with the amount of play in the print head. Tightening the adjustment screw in the slider will take some of the play out of the assembly. However if you tighten it too much you will break the slider and or cause the nylon bearings to become angled. This outer plate fits right on your existing slider. Parts required for this mod are (3) 5mm X 30 Machine screws, (1) 3mm X 25 screw per tower. Printed with ABS and tapped large holes with a 5mm tap, small hole with a 3mm tap. If you want to put a nut on the end of the 5mm screws get 5mm X 35 machine screws.

Printer:

Folgertech Kossel 2020

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.2mm

Infill:

25%

Notes:

The inner hole for the 3mm screw runs almost all the way across the part. Watch the print so you can see how far you need to drill and tap.
Designed this with AutoDesk Fusion 360

title: Australian Tube Products (ATP) Stem Cap
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: Australian Tube Products (ATP) was a company that made handlebars and stems for bicycles. In the 1950’s, they produced the 'The Ray Gun' stem, which was constructed from a few steel tubes which were brazed together, and a plastic cap which was inserted into the rear of the stem. This prevented users from injuring themselves and to keep water and contaminants out of the stem. Over the past 60 years, the plastic cap was either lost or deteriorated from UV exposure.

Printer:

CTC

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

20%

Notes:

ABS is the preferred material due to sun exposure. I printed at 0.2mm layer height for a good balance between print speed and detail. 3 shells with 0.4mm nozzle will be adequate.

The stem cap insertion is set at 20mm, whereas the internal diameter of the stem is 19mm. The oversized stem cap allows for users to sand down the cap to suit individual stems.

Sand and buff or acetone smoothing will end up with a finish similar to the original stem cap.

This component was drawn up in Solidworks with measurements and a reference image and vector path of the original bar plug.

The Solidworks part file has been included for those who would like to make any adjustments.

title: Thread Gauge Heat Insert Guide (in & mm)

description.text:
The design intent was two-fold:
To have useful Imperial & Metric models for checking thread-size on loose screws, and to have readily on hand design guides and visual aids when designing for heat inserts and for gauging thickness of materials.

These models use heat inserts made for plastic. I purchased mine through Mcmaster Carr but you may be able to find them through another supplier. I am not affiliated with Mcmaster in any way but love using their website for things like this, as they have always supplied me with quality products, and always have the design data to use their products right on the website. I have included a PDF example of one of the inserts design data.

Heat inserts are used when you need a permanent brass thread in plastic models. They are small inserts set inside tapered holes designed into your part. The inserts are then heated using a standard soldering iron tip which melts the surrounding plastic. The user then guides the insert with the soldering iron as it sinks to the preferred depth and the plastic melts in around the textured insert forever locking it in place.

The numbers on the 3d printed models are:
TOP - Thread size of heat insert
BOTTOM - Minimum thickness needed for that insert and height of that step
LEFT - small diameter for the insert tapered hole
RIGHT - larger diameter for the insert tapered hole

(Note: I did not purchase all the heat insert models available from that supplier, just the shorter ones I felt I needed. That is why only one side of the pictured models have inserts and the other side is still showing tapered holes.)

Edit: 05/21/16 13:56 CST
Added in Metric_Rev1 model, due to forgetting to change the Inventor export stl settings from imperial to metric. Thus the first version will need to be scaled up by a factor of 25.4 or else it will be miniscule on your print bed. Simplify3d will recognize this scaling factor and ask if you want to convert to metric and it works fine. If your slicer does not allow scaling or conversion, use the Rev1 model. Thanks for the catch reibuehl. :)

comments.text: What size nozzle are you using?  My slicer wants to skip most of the raised text because it's too thin for my .4 nozzle.
comments.author: mikeymakesit

comments.text: What are the two diameters (small and large) for? Do I need to design my holes with one of those depending on the material or top of the hole with large, bottom with small? Would be great if you could explain that a little more. Also the metric file seems to need to be scaled by factor 25.4 if the slicer works in Millimeter.
comments.author: reibuehl

comments.text: Correct, you need to design your holes with a taper to accommodate the required taper and depth of the desired heat insert. The smaller diameter is the root of the taper, the larger diameter is the opening of the taper, the thickness is the minimum thickness or the depth of the tapered hole. Search McMaster Carr website for heat insert and you will see that the numbers on the 3d model match up to their design table of their available inserts. Sorry about the metric scaling. I forgot to set the Inventor stl options to metric. I have added in a metric Rev1 file with proper scaling. Good questions; thanks!
comments.author: reibuehl

Began to learn harmonica.
Started with Puckering. But now i want to learn tongue blocking techniques.
The original Tongue Block Trainers are make from a thin piece auf plastic (1 gallon container ?).
Gallons are not very common in Germany. And even ebay or amazon didn't provide a original trainer.
Of course I could make my self a clone some how, but thinking about it, I decided that I want trainer that is quite realistic.

So I scaled my real harp and made a 3D-Design.
Here it is: A trainer that feels a little bit like a harp.

Printer:

Prusa i3 (PLA)

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.1 - 0.2

Infill:

20%

Notes:

If you print it upside down, you get a nice surface for you tongue. But it is not looking perfect.
If you print it normally, you may add some support. And you have to you sandpaper to make it smoother.

print_settings.Notes:: Only the dispenser BODY requires support when printing.

description.text:
This is a straw dispenser that holds about 30 hard straws, the type that come with yoghurt drinks like Yakut and Vitagen. It accommodates straws under 115mm in length and about 3mm diameter.

Credit to Jack Houweling's wood-crafted Pencil Dispenser for the idea, this 3D printed version is in just 2 parts (3 if you want the cover, or 4 if you need the magnet slot cap if you're using smaller/ thinner magnets), and requires 2 x M3*12mm screws and a pair of short springs. I added two slots at the back to accommodate 4 neodymium magnets (20mm dia, 3mm thick). However I used 1.5 magnets on each side (recycling broken ones). The dispenser holds firm on any metal fridge door/ surface but easy enough for little hands to operate.

Now my kids spend less time in front of an open fridge juggling their drink and straws from the plastic sleeves.

https://youtu.be/FdfDGLOCSgA

Printer Brand:

Printrbot

Printer:

Simple Black

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Infill:

20%

Notes:

Only the dispenser BODY requires support when printing.

comments.text: This may seem like a silly question, but where do the screws go? Do they go through the side and then into the flap? Wouldn't that cause the flap not to pivot?
comments.author: fodelement

comments.text: The screws go in snug through the side and into the flap, but using proper M3 screws (not anything that seems the same size) will provide enough play to move the flap without compromising the flap's position which also serves to retain the other straws from falling out all at once.
comments.author: fodelement

comments.text: Thanks! My printer is probably not configured right then.
comments.author: Simonwlchan

comments.text: You can probably salvage your prints, just bore a hole enough to get the M3 screws through. The flap can be snuggly held by the main body unit, and it should not be floppy. As long as the flap can be moved down with two thumbs or without force it should be fine. The springs should push back into the starting position.
comments.author: fodelement

comments.text: I have changed it a lot.... I will show you when I am done. If you like Batman, I think you will enjoy it. :)
comments.author: Simonwlchan

description.text:
I made this one to reduce the amount of plastic used in the original design. It has been made with tinkercad and meshmixer. Print without supports. Model in pihot printed at .3 layer with 2 shells and 20 % infill.

The location holes have a lot of clearance to stop snow jamming it and the holes go all the way through so any snow in the holes will get pushed out

Printed on a Wanhao I3

Printer:

Wanhao i3

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.3

Infill:

20%

Notes:

2 shells, 4 top layers.

note with the 2 shells the infill percentage doesn't really matter as the shells all but touch as the wall thickness is 3 mm.
The basic shape was designed in tinkercad and then exported to mesh mixer to be made hollow and then cut in half. it was then bought back into tinkercad to add the location pins and holes.

title: Ghostbusters 2016 Proton Pack- Toolbox / Cryogen Chamber Handle

description.text:
This was made using in film reference, notes from crew, as well as detailed photos of the SDCC proton pack and the Olympia pack. Scaled from references based off of known objects on the pack taking into account perspective distortion, viewing angle, and other factors, Measurements were crossed checked among different sources to ensure accuracy.

I can not guarantee this is 100% of course with out first hand access to the real thing but it should be very close. And I hope it helps my fellow prop builders out there. A tiny bit of extra material has been added to the handles finger groves to compensate for material loss during sanding and cleanup.

Made to fit a handle hole that is 5 inches wide, 2 inches tall, and a half inch deep.

Designed to be used with a 4mm cap bolt, the head of the cap bolt should recess about half way into the side holes just like on the screen used packs, and will thread into the handle itself allowing the handle to be held in place and move freely without nuts on the other side.

P.S. -Be careful while handling the handle, if you can't handle it call the professionals-
A tiny bit of extra material has been added to the handles finger groves to compensate for material loss during sanding and cleanup.

Tinkercad

author: maurot2

print_settings.Notes:: Touching buildplate support is enough.

title: Ghostbusters Ghost Trap (1984) for smaller 3D Printers

description.text:
This is a split version of the 3 bigger parts of countspatula's Ghost Trap, allowing it to be printed on printers with a 200x200mm bed.

You will have to print all other parts from the original Ghost Trap if you want the whole thing.

The split parts are designed to be assembled without any glue or extra screws. However, if you want to sand and paint them, it may worth gluing them first.

They assemble perfectly but you may have to do some sanding on the part where support material was attached.
Same thing if you're experiencing "Elephant foot syndrome" (that may be an issue with the bottom frame, but you can fix it easily with some sanding or an X-acto knife).

List of parts:

  • side_LT_panel_s1 and side_LT_panel_s2
    Those two parts replace the original side_LT_panel part. You need to print with supports for the bigger part ("touching buildplate" support is enough).
  • side_RT_panel_GB2_s1 and side_RT_panel_GB2_s2
    Those two parts replace the original side_RT_panel_GB2 part. You need to print with supports for the bigger part ("touching buildplate" support is enough).
  • bottom_frame-MOTOR_s1 and bottom_frame-MOTOR_s1
    Those two parts replace the original bottom_frame-MOTOR part. I didn't made a split version of the "non-motor" part since there are almost the same (one of the holes on the bottom is bigger; even if you're not planning to add a motor you can probably use this version). You need to print with supports for both parts ("touching buildplate" support is enough).
    The triangular rim and slot in the middle part of the joint are a little hard to clean (sorry) but the good news is they don't add any significant structural integrity to the assembled frame so if you clean them too much you'll probably be ok (they are just there to prevent the bottom to bent when you press inward next to the joint).

Some note about the top frame:
While the top frame will fit on a 200x200mm printbed, you will have less than 1mm of clearance on the long side, which will prevent you to use a brim.
Now, printing something that big without a brim can be challenging.
I recommend using "hold down circles" if you can.
If you're using Cura, I made a small utility to generate a "2D brim" that worked fine for this piece. You can find it there: https://github.com/LeFauve/X-Brim-extender-for-Cura

I didn't finish printing every parts yet, but I'm pretty sure those are the only ones that pose problem with a smaller printbed.

Note that I'm doing only the trap! The pedal may have some parts needing a cut too (or not)

Supports:

Yes

Notes:

Touching buildplate support is enough.

comments.text: I've made this for printing on a Wanhao Duplicator i3, but it should work on any 200x200mm printer (probably on a 200x140mm one too, but you may want to double check before starting to print).
comments.author: LeFauve

author: LeFauve

description.text:
I built one of these:
http://www.instructables.com/id/Pong-Word-Clock/
and then I needed a case to put it in. I had just got my 3D printer, so this is my first project designed from scratch. The design includes cutouts and standoffs for the LED panels and also standoffs for the Freetronics Eleven Arduino compatible board that I used for the project. I believe that any Arduino Uno compatible board will also fit the standoff pattern.
You can edit the design using a DXF file editor and OpenSCAD. The basic layout has all been done using 2D DXF files. Each layer that needs to be a different height uses a separate layer in the DXF file. Each layer is then "extruded" to the correct height in OpenSCAD. All extruded objects are added together to make the 3D object.

I printed my box in ABS using 0.4mm layer height and solid infill. Turn on Support Material so that the rectangular cut-outs are nice and neat.
To join the three sections together I used a single piece of clear 3mm perspex across the back.

Two leaf shaped wall hook (one smaller and one bigger).

A interlocking fastening system hides the fastening screw

author: MikeyWires

title: Ghostbusters 2016 Proton Pack- Toolbox/ Cryogen Chamber Lid

description.text:
This was made using in film reference, notes from crew, as well as detailed photos of the SDCC proton pack and the Olympia pack. Scaled from references based off of known objects on the pack taking into account perspective distortion and other factors, Measurements were crossed checked among different sources to ensure accuracy.

I can not guarantee this is 100% of course with out first hand access to the real thing but it should be very close. And I hope it helps the prop builders out there.

Note: the side bolts change positions from pack to pack, this positions I based off of the SDCC Holtzmann pack, The top rivets appear to be consistent among different packs with the exception of the pack that has the proton guns slide out of the side as that pack has more rivets and appears to be a bigger box in general for the scene.

Included are different handles in different stages of completion, so if you wish to tweak this design (as I don't feel it is 100% exact yet) I hope these tools will help.

Handle that is centered above the lid is made to fit a handle hole that is 5 inches wide, 2 inches tall, and a half inch deep.Designed to be used with a 4mm cap bolt, the head of the cap bolt should recess about half way into the side holes just like on the screen used packs, and the bolts will thread into the handle itself allowing it to be held in place and move freely without nuts on the other side.
This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/iAe5l9pZVzb

title: Embroidery hoop, square, parametric (e.g. for lettering)

description.text:
This is a parametric embroidery hoop that can be adapted to the needs of your sewing machine. The idea is to attach this hoop to an X/Y stage, which moves the hoop under the needle of a sewing machine.
There are commercial alternatives available... but why spend more than £100 when you can print it for two orders of magnitude less?!
The roundness of the hoop can be adjusted by changing the
roundedCornerRadius. But anyway, all variables are in my opinion relatively well documented in the code.

22 May 2016: Uploaded v1.1. Fixed a problem with slightly too large overall dimensions caused by rounded corners. Added watermark.

19 June 2016: Uploaded v1.3 thicker hoops.

Printer:

MiniCNCPrinterCutter

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

15

Notes:

I would suggest to adapt the thickness of the hoops to a multiple of your extrusion width.
I print this one in PETG for durability. There is no reason why ABS and PLA shouldn't print equally well.

comments.text: This is great.  My daughter just broke her hoop, and this will let me create a new custom one using the included scad file.  Many Thanks

description.text:
Do you have problems cooking spaghettis? Every time you have to choose a fair portion per person you fail miserably? That's because you are not using the:

FLIYING SPAGHETTI MONSTER PORTION MEASURER !!!

You have two holes, a portion for one person, and a portion for two! Oh no! Tonight Tommy and their friends come home and we' ll be five! Don' t worry! just use the two persons hole twice, and an aditional one of the single portion!

Life is beatiful! Isn' t it?

As the SFM says:

"I am the Flying Spaghetti Monster. Thou shalt have no other monsters before Me. (Afterwards is OK; just use protection.) The only Monster who deserves capitalization is Me! Other monsters are false monsters, undeserving of capitalization."

Remember that the SFM loves you! (maybe not but who knows)

print_settings.Notes:: I can try to print it in ABS. But i think the most people will have problems to print such big parts with out warping. So i switched from ABS to PLA to get a very flat, warepage-free surface.

description.text:
Spinning Tool for cats.
Have also one from the factory. But i don't like the way they are moving the rod.
So the bought toy is a bit boring for the cats.

I planned to use an ESP8266-Wifi-Modul to control it.
Tests with an Arduino look good. Cat were interested ;-)

https://vimeo.com/208030539

Update: Many months later I tried out the different chip systems.
The ESP8266 needed to much power in the standby mode.
Finally I went for the cheap 433MHz-OOK-Moduls and a Arduino Nano.
So I can control it by it a old remote control for sockets or my openhab home automation system that contains a 433MHz-OOK-Transmitter anyway.

You can download my code as well.
The init-sequence helps to find the working range of your servo.
by examble: T0800 is moving the servo to the 800ms milliseconds position. If it works for you, you can save the value as lower border by "L0800". Same with upper border.

The construction is not a nice design.
It is just stable, easy to print and provides enough space for electronic and batteries.
I did spend some extra time to make it printable without any support.

You will need some 3mm screw and nuts to mount a rod on the device.
The bearing is not necessary but i reduces the force to the servo-axis.
The arm of the servo is glued from the inside to the cover. The hole in the cover let you screw cover and servo together.

The FreeCAD-Files show the latest upgrades and bug fixes. The STL-files just contain the prototyp you see in the picture.
So it is recommend to make a fresh export from the design-data!

Printer:

Prusa i3 (PLA)

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0,2 - 0,3

Infill:

15%

Notes:

I can try to print it in ABS. But i think the most people will have problems to print such big parts with out warping. So i switched from ABS to PLA to get a very flat, warepage-free surface.

author: NOP21

print_settings.Notes:: Laser cutting

description.text:
We have made several printers (3 iterations and 85+ printers) and have been working from the P3Steel frame. We changed and added features to the very nicely designed frame Leonardo. We have included the x-axis from the Alu. version but made it in 3 mm stainless steel (ASTM304).

A very special thank to Jakob for handling the drawings, and all others for input and suggestions grand job to you all.

We have called it the AUP3Steel and added/changed:
0) Distributed into individual drawings and added the laser cut x-axis as standard to the frame.
1) "Flaps" and mounting holes for smooth rod for the y axis.
2) Mounting holed for Ramps 1.4 and Melzi boards on the side panels (due to asymmetry it only bolts on the right side of the plates).
3) Added holes for mounting "whatever design" to hold the threaded rod and smooth rod for the z axis.
4) Removed the press nut for the z xais - now you have to tread the two plates.
5) Added mounting holes on the x-sled (bolting on extrudes), holes for mounting sensors on the x-axis.
6) one or two things I have forgotten... Mostly extra holes here and there.

All files are in PDF and DXF for sending directly for Laser cutting or modification if you feel like

Printer:

AUP3Steel

Notes:

Laser cutting
Tread the plates for the z-xais.
We did not design this we are standing on the shoulder of a lot of brilliant folks! Thanks to all!

comments.text:
I have been asked:
Is this the newest version of your drawings?

comments.text: Yes - we are working on it. It will arrive when we are ready. Maybe we will make a homepage for it and then the link will arrive here. But in general it follows the "normal" P3Steel - so for most of the work it is given (follow the remix links and wiki). BOM will be added to.

author: Crazzy118

print_settings.Notes:: Nozzle Size: 0.4

description.text:
I Created this display mount to be used with the Full Graphic Smart LCD Controller case:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:87250

It was a nice case, but I wanted to use it with my MAKERFRONT i3PROXL 3D printer.
So I designed this in TinkerCad. I printed it with 100% infill ( I wanted it to be strong).
I used OrbPolymer ABS 1.75 filament and it turned out well for me.
I used three m3 40mm in length socket screws that I purchased from Bolt Depot.

One socket screw is m3 12mm in length. The hole in the front is for an 11 inch
plastic zip tie to keep it in place, but it fits so tight I am not using one. I did not
want to alter the frame by drilling holes and this case is the best anyway!

I just added the new file with a cutaway for the SD card. No need for pliers to
take SD card out. That would be the file named: final_of_lcd12864_holder.stl

Printer:

MAKERFRONT i3PRO3XL

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.2

Infill:

100

Notes:

I used a brim when I printed my mount.

Layer Height: 0.2
Shell thickness: .8

Fill
Bottom/Top thickness: 0.8
Fill Density %: 100

Print speed: 90

Printing temperature: 230
Bed Temperature: 100

Support: Brim

Filament
OrbPolymer ABS
Diameter: 1.75
Flow: 100

Nozzle Size: 0.4

How I designed this

I used my electronic calipers and took measurements of the frame thickness.

I then measured the case dimensions. I figured out what dimensions I
needed and loaded up TinkerCad with some square shapes and sized
them to what I needed. I added the slots by dropping some square
shapes and turning them into holes and adjusting them so not to use
too much plastic.

I tried to line up the holes where the three m3 40mm socket screws
go to screw the case and mount together. I kept printing out a thin
layer to check alignment and then I would stop the printer.

It worked so I stopped working on the holes. Feel free to make them
better. After all this I should have made a cutaway for accessing
the smartcard. I use a pair of small needle nose pliers to pull the
card out. In the future I will add a cutaway.

I am sure this will work with less infill. I printed it at 100% because
I wanted a strong mount. This mount with the display will not
interfere with the height of models in your MAKERFRONT printer.
In fact it is not in the wires way either!

title: J-Max_Bowden Belt Extruder (feeder) V1.0
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
French version : http://www.j-max.fr/?p=632

English :

Fade up about plastic gears noise, let me introduce you to my Bowden Belt Extruder v1.0. It's quiet and effective with a 4:1 reduction ratio. This is a compact feeder compared to RichRap's. The belt tensioning is assumed by a radial insert of the motor. The unibody feeder is very stiff for enhanced extrusion precision. We added a crank to the secondary pulley to allow to feed/unfeed the filament quick and easy. The lock inspired from the lulzbot Taz5 one allows a quick release in no time to access to the hobbed gear easily for maintenance, through, because the tight fit of the filament guidance you don't realy need to open the idler to insert a new filament.

See video for further presentation : https://youtu.be/mSWpEaICI2o
Or for assembly instructions : https://youtu.be/LU_pFnTfH9M

The extrudeur was in beta mode during 6 months and had 4 beta testers (thanks to my friends at the KB group ;) ) Several versions of the parts leaded to that V1.0 extruder that we don't have actualy nothing to complain about.

Actualy, I don't think it's necessary to develop any 3mm extruder, as it will soon RIP (here in europe, the shops are doing sales on that diameter).

Add-ons
There is different body versions. Big thanks to Rexipus for his version of the body part to be mounted on horizontal rails OpenBuilds 2020 profiles (please note a little file job may be required, and this version does not fit for 2020 module 6 or 5mm, use original mounting holes instead.). You can print the body part reversed, as Rexipus did, for more comfort or to mount two extruders side by side. Huge Thanks to Denis (digiTALker) who have worked on an 200mm belt body version. Big thanks To Phil (sysimgrp) who designed interesting parts : a longer crank extension for more comfort if you have enough space and a great clamp head which uses no springs.

Many thanks to the maker's community to help making this small idea at the start of a bowden belt extruder to become a much versatile extruder with extra parts options to fit a large field of uses. You guys are awesome !

BOM :

Hardware :
1x Nema17 motor (any kind at last 34mm long)
1x GT2 2mm 80 tooth closed loop belt
1x GT2 2mm 16 tooth regular pulley
4x DIN912 M3x8mm screws (for motor mount)
1x DIN912 M3x20mm Screw (for idler's bearing mount)
1x DIN912 M3x25mm Screw (for idler mount)
1x DIN912 M3x30mm Screw (for crank mount)
2x DIN912 M3x40mm Screws (for the lock system) AND add a M3x30mm if you choose Phil's springless lock.
1x DIN912 M5x40mm Screw (for the hobbed gear/secondary pulley axis) /!\ File a flat side for the MK7 Screw OR M5x50mm if you choose Phil's Extanded Crank.
5x DIN985 M3 Nylstop nuts (for M3 screws except obviously 8mm ones)
1x DIN985 M5 Nylstop nut (for the secondary pulley fixing)
1x M3 washer (any kind will fit, even if we use Nylon ones - used for the crank)
2x DIN127 M5 grover washer (for the hobbed gear/secondary pulley axis)
1x M5 washer (any kind will fit - used for the secondary pulley alignment)
1x 623 bearing (for idler bearing)
2x MF105 bearing (for the hobbed gear/secondary pulley axis)
2x 4x20mm springs (actualy we use recycled pencil ones - used for the lock system)
1x 3/8" 4mm push in fitting (for bowden 4mm teflon tube)
1x MK7 Hobbed gear (better than the MK8 IMHO)

/!\ Pay attention to buy a proper MK7 hobbed gear for 1.75mm filaments. The universal MK7 for both 1.75 and 3mm filament may not suit perfectly. The perfect dimensions are : 5mm bore ; 11mm tall ; 12mm (or 1/2") in diameter ; a 3mm wide hobbed groove centered at 3mm from the top, with an inner diameter of the grove of 11mm (10.5mm is still acceptable). Some cheap MK7 measures 12mm in height but you still can file or grind it a few to make it suit.

Pastic printed parts :
1x Feeder body
1x GT2 64 tooth secondary pulley
1x Crank for secondary pulley
1x Idler
1x Lock

Necessary tools :

  • 1.4mm Allen Hex key (for hobbed gear and GT2 16T pulley)
  • 2.5mm Allen Hex key (for M3 screws)
  • 4mm Allen Hex key (for M5 screw)
  • 5.5mm wrench for M3 nuts
  • 8mm wrench for M5 nuts
  • 9.5mm wrench for pneufit
  • thin plyers (for deburing)
  • utility knife (for deburing)
  • 3mm bit (for deburing)
  • 5mm bit (for deburing)
  • a gas lighter (for deburing stringing)

See video for deburing and mounting details. Note it could be useful to make a small nocht with a file on the M5x40 shaft. This will help the MK7 screw to hold in place.

I wrote the story of that extruder on : https://www.instructables.com/id/Bowden-Belt-Extruder/

/!\ the part named "J-Max_BowdenBeltExtruder_Body2020OpenBuildsByRexipus.stl" is mirrored. If you chose this model, you must print both the idler and clamp par mirored to match this body part.

Printer Brand:

RepRap

Printer:

Prusa I3, CoreXY

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

at last 0.3mm 2mm layers

Infill:

at last 50%

Notes:

Please set "supports everywhere", and prefer strong filaments : ABS, PETG, Carbon fibre reinforced PETG, POM, PC. Note, this is a compact feeder, a high infill level in relationship with your filament type is necessary to prevent any twist during operation.

What to do, just out of the build plate.

comments.author: billkaroly

comments.text:
Hi J-Max,
Thank you for sharing your extruder design. I have been using it for over a year and I am very pleased with it. It is a very clever design and obviously well thought out. I couldn't find the MK7 gear that met your specifications. The ones I could find had a smaller inner diameter for the groove of only 10 to 10.2 mm and were 13 mm tall. Because of the smaller diameter, the springs did not provide enough clamping pressure to keep the filament from slipping. I modified the idler clamp to replace the springs with a screw mechanism that provides adjustable tension on the filament. I also put a 'groove' in the body to accept the taller MK7 gear.
comments.author: sysimgrp

comments.text: I found some MK7 gears that have a 10.54mm inner diameter and meet all the other specs. reprap.me has them.
comments.author: sysimgrp

comments.text: Thanks, that is good to know.  Meanwhile, J-Max has generously added my redesigned clamp that allow the extruder to work with the smaller inner diameter MK7 gear and provides positive clamping pressure.  He has also include the crank extension.

comments.text:
Well, I'm afraid this would not work because of the shaft distance. The middle tensioning distance between the shaft is +-37mm on my extruder body. You should need a too big pulley which will collision with the 16T pulley. Through, you won't have enough teeth in mesh and the belt will jump over teeth under the torque. You should make a remix of my extruder body with the same pulleys and a medium shaft distance of +-58mm.
++JM
comments.author: Japim

comments.text: Yup - I did it. I set the pulleys 58mm apart as proposed. In general the body is 10mm longer and 10mm taller comparing to your slender design. And I also made the body a little bit wider due to bigger 625 bearings. It can also accept the longer MK7 gear. Because of this the clamp had to be widened as well. The clearance around the filament openings is made very tight - so you may even try to use flexible filament w/o the risk for escaping to the sides. The only original part I left is your pulley - that I left with the original marking for recognition of your original design.

comments.author: PuterPro

comments.text: Drill plastic backward ... I KNEW  that but forgot it, thanks! My "plastics" trick is: I worked in a place where we had to screw together and apart assemblies with sharp steel screws into plastic bosses. Sometimes 10 times! As you can guess they stripped a lot ...! We learned to always run the screws slowly backwards in an already threaded hole, feel it "click" at the start of the threads, then go forward slowly. If tight, STOP and try again, if smooth, you're in the original thread pattern! I do it without thought now.
comments.author: J-Max

comments.text: Hi,

comments.text: Well, it IS a hobby for me, so frustrating as it may be, it's fun overcoming the obstacles! Keeps my brain flexible. No problem on the CAD files.
