title: Speed Handle for a PanaVise Jr.

description.text:
This is a Speed Handle for a PanaVise(tm) Jr. vise.  With it, you can open and close the jaws much faster and more easily than using the stock handle which comes with the vise.  For some period of time, PanaVise provided these along with these vises.
The knob fits securely over the vise's existing knob.

• Build the gcode for handle.stl and then print.
  • Press fit the handle onto your vise over its existing handle.
  • If the handle doesn't quite fit then you can tweak handle.scad and generate a revised .stl file to your liking.

author: paulminize

description.text:
A while ago I started calibrating my extruder temperature for my various rolls of filament, which (for those who don't know) involves running a single print that gradually changes temperature and then reviewing afterward where the print looks the best in terms of layer adhesion, overhangs, bridging, etc. To do this, we need to edit our sliced gcode file before sending it to the printer and insert the various temperatures we'd like the extruder to reach. While it's not particularly hard to edit the gcode file by hand in a text editor I wrote a python script to automate the process.



My routine now whenever I get a new roll of filament is to:

  1. check the recommended temperature range as given on the filament
  2. create a customised model with that range
  3. slice the model
  4. run the gcode file through the python script
  5. print
  6. review the print then mark the optimal temp on the side of the spool

Some examples to use for a customised temp tower can be found via: ellipticaloptician, eibwen,


Instructions

When slicing your stl file it is a good idea (but not strictly necessary) to set the printing temperature in your slicer settings to the starting temperature you intend to test.

To use the script you'll need to have python installed. Simply drag and drop your gcode file onto the python scripts icon then follow the prompts to enter three parameters:

  1. your starting temperature
  2. your final temperature
  3. the amount at which the temperature should change

The script will then tell you which temps will print at which height.


Which Slicer?

The script will auto-detect and handle output from a few different slicers (and across a few different versions). If you receive the message saying your slicer "isn't yet supported", you can upload your gcode somewhere and send me the link and I'll add it.


Edits

26/05/2016 - updated script (more robust)
21/09/2016 - updated script to handle output from another slicer
19/06/2017 - added a separate script for CURA users
06/12/2017 - consolidated the separate versions into one. added: auto-detection for different slicer output; various safety checks; and a couple of requested features


Disclaimer

Please only use this script if you understand what you're doing. I accept no responsibility if you damage your printer!

title: Lens cap holder for both 58 and 52 mm lens diameters

description.text:
I primarily use lenses that are either 52 or 58 mm diameters, so I wanted a lens cap holder for my black rapid strap that could hold both. Included in the model are rings with a .75 mm pitch and .75 mm depth to match the lens cap. This gives a better hold than smooth sides that some other models have.

I strongly recommend printing these at as high a resolution as you can. I used .05 mm heights to make sure the rings came out well. I'm very happy with the final product.

Also, if you haven't tried a black rapid strap, check them out. They're great.

description.text:
Apologies for the rough print - this was the test print of the final changes to the model(s) to get it working perfectly.

Print all the parts and you'll also need a standard 9g servo and an old clickable pen.

To build it (video about this coming soon)
1) Print all parts and test fit slide into case, you may need to file a little off the sides to it moves freely
2) Sand the ends of the hooks until they are a firm push fit into the slide (the opening should face towards the rear
3) Sand the 4mm block until it's a tight fit into the bottom of the case
4) push the plate across the bottom of the case and then adjust the spacing of the hooks so they don't pinch and release the plate when slid forward
5) Once happy with the fit, use glue to secure the rear post into the case and the hooks into the slide.
6) remove any excess from the hooks on the back part of the slide
7) fit the spring over the guide in the slide and test that it's strong enough to keep the hooks engaged in flight
7) fit the servo and attach a short arm, it should only be 3mm over the edge of the servo
8) Test with radio and set endpoints for a switch so that one position the servo is just not touching the slide and the other position the slide is all the way forward but the servo isn't buzzing
9) Check that the plate falls from the case
10) fit the plate to whatever you want to drop! (See the RC Bomb from a soda bottle)
11) Use the screws from the servo to secure the lid in place (see images). I drilled a small pilot hole. Or you could simply glue the lid in place.

Enjoy!

author: sevelin

description.text:
Hi
This is my own little Smartrap version with Ramps, heatbed, and max printing volume.

Its still under construction.

I added an adapter for this display housing:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:905368

For Z axis i prefer to use this coupler:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:602481

I build this spool holder and i think its the best solution:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:508896

BOM:
8 mm rods:
2 x 300 mm
4 x 400 mm
18 x M8 female screw
2 x threades rods 8 mm x 200xx
3 x threades rods 5 mm x 310, 350, 300 mm
12 x LM8UU Linear Bearing
4 x Nema 17 ( I used the 0,4 A Version)
Ramps electronics with heatbed, 2004 LCD and 3 Endstops
Springs for the extruder and the heatbed leveling
MK8 Gear
1 x Connector for the bowden hose at the extruder
1 x bearing for extruder (i will update the type soon)

And last but not least, a lot of M3 / M4 / M5 screws ;)

My final prototype isn't running yet ;)

Stay tuned

2016.05.24 Display mount added
2016.06.02 My prototype works. Photos coming soon
2016.06.04 Added photos and Handle_V2 with Leading for threaded rod
2016.08.03 Added extruder lever V2

I built 2 of them. Both with the rods and both are working very precisely. I bend the rods slightely to the gears, so the they never work without contact to the gears.
Be free to design a remix with GT2 belts ;). Momentary i have no time to design a new one.

Simple solution for those with cracked housing near hinges. Print this with 70-80% infill or more for maximum strength. Fits very tight.  
My lid broke on both sides, and it was just hanging loose on some other parts and wires. Needed to be supported by wall or something.   
This clamps hold everything in one piece and it works jut fine. Well you can't still close the lid, but you can use your lenovo without worries of breaking it completly.  
STL contains both, left and right clamp. Even if you have your lenovo cracked on one side, or not cracked at all, i recommend using it on both sides to prevent future damages.

title: Custom Onion Dome Rocket Nose Cone

description.text: This is a custom nose cone for an Estes model rocket.  This one fits a "Code Red" model rocket that I picked up at Fry's Electronics, but the concept could work for any rocket--just tweak the diameter to fit into the body tube.

Print out and slap on yer rocket. I printed with one shell and no support, and my part came out weighing 5g, compared to the 15g of the original (and much longer) nose cone. There's a hole at the base of the part to tie the parachute and shock cord.
Enjoy, and happy launching! If you have a successful launch with a custom cone, share it in the comments!

comments.text: So much for aerodynamics lol. But it does look pretty cool.

<iframe allowfullscreen="None" frameborder="0" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/0iHAuDdef8k" ></iframe>

This is a support for an RPSMA antenna plug for the FrSky Taranis RC controller, replacing the built in fixed antenna. The support fits an unmodified case, and is quite sturdy. Should also work for an SMA connector, if you so prefer.

Build with thick top/bottom layers (e.g. 1.0 mm) and reasonably high in-fill. I used PLA, but ABS may possibly be better.

You can fine tune the tolerance parameter for a perfect fit with your printer.

It needs two M3 screws for assembly, either cylinder head or recessed.
The threaded holes should be tread using an M3 tap, or use the version with two M3 nuts instead. The version with the nuts is probably stronger, and preferred.

A description of how to replace the fixed antenna with an external connector is here: http://www.rcgroups.com/forums/showthread.php?t=2129736 RPSMA pig tails and 2.4 GHz antennas (and uFL PCB coax connectors, if desired) are readily available from many places, for instance Adafruit.

For alternative to this design, see for instance http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:733022 and http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1063873 and http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1130405
Borderlands logo stand for printing, should print without any support at all. Enjoy
A knob for a 6 mm D shaft - for rotary encoders etc. The design is optimized for 3D printing, with an easily removable support ring below the center part.

description.text: I'll use this space to list any amendments and additions I make to the original D-Bot. Thus far I have only made a small number of amendments. I have a number of STL's too upload and will likely do so once I have my printer running and the parts operationally tested.

This model of a Lewis Structure is made up of 3 simple parts; the base, the element chip, and the pegs, which represent valence electrons. Once printed the model can be used as a manipulative to model the relationship between an elements group on the periodic table and the number of valence electrons the element has. This model can also be used to simulate ionic bonds by printing multiple bases and element chips.

Printer Brand:

MakerBot

Printer:

MakerBot Replicator Mini
Use this to model Lewis Structures and the formation of Ionic bonds
Coming soon

Lewis Structure Model

Overview:

Objectives:

  • model the relationship between elements in the same group on the periodic table and the number of valence electrons of the elements atoms.
  • model the process of ionic bonding
  • create chemical formulas of ionic compounds while modeling the process of ionic bonding

Audience:
8-12 grade

Subjects:
Physical Science, Chemistry

Standards:
NGSS:
HS-PS1-1. Use the periodic table as a model to predict the relative properties of elements based on the patterns of electrons in the outermost energy level of atoms.

HS-PS1-2. Construct and revise an explanation for the outcome of a simple chemical reaction based on the outermost electron states of atoms, trends in the periodic table, and knowledge of the patterns of chemical properties.

Lesson:

Duration:

Preparation:

Assessment:

comments.text:
I love this pegboard representation of Lewis structures for teaching ion formation!
I'm just beginning to learn about 3D printing, and don't know yet how complicated various parts of the programming might be. But, I'm wondering whether you could show the correct upper/lowercase chemical symbols (for example, so that sodium is "Na" instead of "NA") - since students often have a hard time remembering to do that and we want to reinforce the correct notation. Is there an easy way to make that change in my files?

comments.text: I designed this on tinkerCAD.com and what from what I can tell does not support lowercase text. I would think you would need to use a different 3d design software. If you know of something free I can use let me know and I will change the files.

remixed_from.author: arijaycomet
remixed_from.title: Raspberry Pi 2/B+ case for Lulzbot Mini

title: Lulzbot Mini Raspberry Pi (Model B) Case

description.text:
This case allows the mounting of a Raspberry Pi (Model B) onto the side of a Lulzbot Mini. The case is a remix of the Raspberry Pi (Model B) case with 75mm VESA mount by 0110-M-P and the mounting bracket from Raspberry Pi 2/B+ case for Lulzbot Mini by arijaycomet.

I've included 0110-M-P's original top stl file here for convenience, though the bottom piece is the only one that has changed. See 0110-M-P's original case for the source stp files.

See photos and information bellow for information on assembly hardware and mounting.

The following hardware was used to assemble the case:

2x - Sheet metal screw, phillips pan head, #4 x 1/4"
https://www.boltdepot.com/Sheet_metal_screws_Phillips_pan_head_Stainless_steel_18-8_4.aspx?Selected=5435

3x - Sheet metal screw, phillips pan head, #4 x 3/4"
https://www.boltdepot.com/Sheet_metal_screws_Phillips_pan_head_Stainless_steel_18-8_4.aspx?Selected=2298

Design intent was to obtain an adjustable mount for the Logitech C920 webcam in order to watch my 3d printer remotely. Because different prints required different fields of view for optimal watching, I needed ways to have different levels of zoom in and out, angle adjustment, rotation left or right, or height adjustment up and down.

I did not want the webcam mount attached to the printer - to avoid vibration in the view. The solution here is what I developed to mount to the closet door that the printer works in. I can simply loosen the 3 screws to adjust height, rotation, and zoom field of view. The camera itself has an adjustable arm up and down, with a forward and backward tilting head.

Because of the constant loosening and tightening of the screws I opted to use heat inserts for plastic from McMaster Carr. Heat inserts are little brass inserts heated up with a standard soldering iron and sunk into the designed tapered hole. I've attached a pdf of design specs for a random size heat insert.

I really only needed one heat insert on the bottom of the camera cradle, but chose to put one on each side as well in case I ever wanted to mount the whole thing sideways. I've also used this mount upside down pyramid style loose on my desk. So it is pretty versatile to fit my needs.

Materials Needed:
One 8-32 .185" brass heat insert
One 8-32 x 3/8" screw
Two attachment screws that can fit in the 3/16 slots to hold it fast to your door/wall/desk.

Size:
3.75" wide
4.50" tall
4.25" long
.1875" thickness

comments.text: I can't get the correct size for the print files.  Is there anything I can do to fix that?
comments.author: ArcaneZorro

comments.text: This is exactly what I needed!  Is the brass heat insert necessary or does it just prevent damage to the holster?
comments.author: ArcaneZorro

comments.text: It was designed with the heat inserts in mind. I highly recommend getting a pack as you will find yourself using them in a lot of your future designs. However, you may be able to use the design without the heat insert as long as the fastener is large enough to grab on to the hole sides without being to large of a diameter for the slots in the L shaped piece. Let me know how it goes. Have a great day!
comments.author: ArcaneZorro
